instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Hello,

Working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that was easily the dirtiest computer that I've ever worked on.  Airflow from one fan was completely blocked. The computer was brought to me as "no power".  Magsafe 85W goes green, so one-wire seems ok but no fan spin.  After extensive cleaning with no apparent corrosion found, I've been troubleshooting.  I jumped the gun on a replacement of <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> that was reporting 0.321V and after replacement nothing changed.  Don't know why I did that.

In any event, <TRANSISTOR>Q7770</TRANSISTOR> pin 5 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) is 12.57V but then pins 1-5 are all 0.321V.  <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> also has 12.57V on pin 5 but then <SIGNAL>P5VS5_LL</SIGNAL> (pins 1-3) and <SIGNAL>P5VS5_DRVH</SIGNAL> are all 0.00V.  Am I misunderstanding the schematic or should those be present when the board is plugged in?

Looking towards <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP5VS5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> is 0.00V and that's where I lose the plot.  Resistance in Ohms of <RESISTOR>R7200</RESISTOR> is 71.5k (specified as 75k).  <TRANSISTOR>Q7210</TRANSISTOR> pin 2 <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 3.412V, <RESISTOR>R7210</RESISTOR> resistance is 9.97k (close enough to 10k, I think). 

Possible for multiple things to be wrong with the board, so I'm guessing that I'll be in for some work.  Hoping for some suggestions as to what to test next to find the fault source(s) and also thoughts on where I did redundant or unnecessary troubleshooting, besides the obvious unnecessary replacement of <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Did you replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> with new, low ESR too?
Do not use hot air there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Yes it was low ESR - Panasonic 2TPE330MFB that I ordered from Digikey - arrived earlier today.  I used the iron on it also based on what I read in another post here about hot air for that.

I've had good success with both Digikey and Mouser but I'm always open to suggestions on other component sources too.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Board cannot start with 0.3V on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>; try another cap.
Check <RESISTOR>R7751</RESISTOR>/80/81.
Post <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> voltages, pins 1, 2, 4, 12; use surrounding components as test points.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
I have no problem replacing <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> but is the problem upstream or before <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> though?

<RESISTOR>R7751</RESISTOR> (pin 2, which corresponds to pin 12 of <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>) is 5.055V.  Resistance to ground in ohms is 4.2k.
<RESISTOR>R7780</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>P1V05S5_VSNS</SIGNAL>) is 0.322V.  Resistance to ground at <RESISTOR>R7780</RESISTOR> is only 490 ohms.  That voltage matches what I'm seeing from <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>.
<RESISTOR>R7781</RESISTOR> appears to be 0.00V and I can't seem to get a good resistance reading for it.

<CHIP>U7750</CHIP>, pin 1 is 12.57V, pin 2 is 5.055V, pin 4 is 3.326V, and pin 12 5.055V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Sorry, I meant 0.3V on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> in last post; corrected now...

You should get an ohm reading for <RESISTOR>R7781</RESISTOR> too; change it, if not.
You may need to change <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> too.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7770</CAPACITOR> is good also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Yes, I assumed as much on the reference to the voltage for <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, no worries.

Resistance to ground of <RESISTOR>R7781</RESISTOR> is 0.4 ohm which seems quite low.

I'm looking for components to remove from old boards but I fear grabbing an already dead cap.  I can't seem to find an exact match for the specs of <CAPACITOR>C7770</CAPACITOR> (0.1UF 10% 25V X5R spec in a 402 package).  As a general rule, when that happens is it ok to substitute with slightly different specifications such as different voltage rating (higher is ok?) or different tolerance?  I think I'm asking generally, are there certain specs on a capacitor that should never be compromised or are there "close enough" values so I don't have to keep searching for an elusive cap?  Same question for resistors too:  If I can't find an exact match for a 4.42K 1% 1/16W 402, which (if any) of the specifications can be compromised?

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
"Resistance to ground of <RESISTOR>R7781</RESISTOR> is 0.4 ohm which seems quite low."
Depends which pin you've checked; one is connected to ground!

For capacitors must find same value and voltage can be higher.
Higher voltage means bigger case sometime; you may have problem to solder it in place.

Tolerance no matters, you must choose the closest value.
In case of <RESISTOR>R7780</RESISTOR>/81 important is to maintain the raport Ra/Rb as close as possible, so you can change both accordingly.

Resistor size can import for lower ohm values; lower size, less current supported.
You can solder 0402 in place of 0201, if the traces allow that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
Thank you much for the information on capacitor and resistor substitutions.  Do you happen to know if <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> is ISL6269A or ISL6269B?  The datasheet for the "B" version is "with audio clamp" but appears to have the same specifications and pinout.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no fan
threads.message:
The code should be visible on the chip.
I don't think to be important here...
